explanation: The report is correct. LFS_ASSERT is defined as assert(test), and the asserted expression calls lfs_mlist_isopen which has no side effects (only returns a boolean). In normal/nominal operation that condition is always true, so the call and its evaluation only perform a check and do not affect program state. Because assert can be compiled out via NDEBUG, that entire operation can be removed without changing program behaviour in the normal case — which meets the definition of dead code in MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. (Note: one can argue removal could alter timing or change behaviour if an assertion ever fails at runtime, but the rule concerns operations whose removal would not affect behaviour; given the shown usage and definition, the assertion evaluation qualifies as dead code.)
